title: Norwich 1-3 Man Utd: 5 talking points as Anthony Martial inspires Red Devils to win
text:

After going 33 weeks without an away victory, Manchester United made it two in the space of four days with a commanding win over Norwich at Carrow Road.

The Red Devils were comfortable winners, despite missing TWO penalties against the Canaries, thanks to first-half goals by Scott McTominay and Marcus Rashford.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer changed formation to accommodate Daniel James, Rashford and Anthony Martial in attack, removing a centre-half and reverting to his preferred 4-2-3-1 shape.

But it was the game’s outstanding player, Scott McTominay, who opened the scoring, firing into the bottom corner moments after Martial had been denied by a stunning save by Tim Krul.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

A dismal VAR decision gave United the chance to double their lead, when Ben Godfrey was adjudged to have taken down James, despite the ex-Swansea winger appearing to lean into the England Under-21 captain.

But Rashford, who had already missed one penalty this term, fluffed his lines, denied by Krul.

Rashford made amends moments later however, racing through after a brilliant James pass, and finishing coolly.

(Image: Joe Toth/BPI/REX)

VAR intervened again just before the break, this time rightly giving United a penalty for handball by Cantwell - but this time Martial was denied by another Krul stop.

Teemu Pukki missed a golden chance to get Norwich on the scoresheet a minute after half-time, firing wide from close range.

And Martial got the goal a fine individual performance deserved, delicately dinking over Krul to make it 3-0 after being found by Rashford.

Onel Hernandez secured a late consolation for the hosts, scoring a fine individual effort of his own, but Solskjaer will leave East Anglia delighted with a solid display from his side.

Here are five talking points from Carrow Road...

1. Solskjaer pinning his hopes on Martial

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Solskjaer couldn't make it more plain after Martial scored on his return to the starting lineup in Belgrade that he sees the Frenchman as his No.9.

He even took a little pop at predecessors Jose Mourinho and Louis van Gaal for playing him out wide.

“Anthony got put out on the wing by other managers and I understand why because he is so quick. But, for me, he is a proper No.9. He needs to be connected to the game."

Duly, despite a draw with Liverpool and the win against Partizan, Solskjaer changed formation to bring Martial into his attack, returning to the 4-2-3-1 formation with which he started the season.

And Martial certainly did his bit to help inspire United's attack. Yes, he missed a penalty but his overall display was good, linking those around him and he did get his goal, with a classy dinked finish.

2. More penalty problems

(Image: Getty Images)

Rashford (2), Martial and Paul Pogba have all missed from the penalty spot now this season for Solskjaer's men, who have missed four of six from the spot.

It didn't cost them here, but they need to really nail it down because it turned a win at Wolves into a draw and a draw with Palace into a defeat.

3. Aarons impresses

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

While Norwich may be falling somewhat short, finding themselves in the relegation zone, young England under-21 full-back Max Aarons is really stepping up to the plate.

Defensively he still has to learn a fair bit - he can be naive with his positioning, as shown on Rashford's goal - but going forwards he's a real threat from deep.

At the beginning of both halves he created two standout chances, both time driving down the right and smartly pulling the ball back for a teammate; unfortunately the finishes couldn't match his approach play.

Certainly Ashley Young will be happy to be away from him; the United skipper was booked for a crude challenge on the youngster, having been skinned a couple of times by Aarons.

4. McTominay and James stepping up

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

If it is to be a youth revolution at Old Trafford under Solskjaer, then McTominay and James are both showing themselves to be the examples to follow, and again they showed here why the Norwegian trusts them.

The Scotland international was excellent for the most part here, commanding at the heart of midfield, using the ball well, initiating attacks and also protecting his defence. He wouldn't have been a regular under Ferguson - think more Wes Brown and John O'Shea - but this isn't that United and you can't knock him for that.

James is adapting to life on the right wing, where he offers a direct threat with his speed. That won United a penalty and launched a number of counters, with Jamal Lewis struggling to deal with him.

But he also produced a number of real quality deliveries and passes - most notably for Rashford's strike. The Welshman continues to grow and add more depth to his all-round game.

5. 2000 just done it

McTominay's opener meant the Scot carved out his own slice of history at Carrow Road.

His strike was United's 2000th in the Premier League.

It also meant United are the first team to score 2000 Premier League goals.

McTominay joins illustrious company in reaching his milestone; Dimitar Berbatov notched number 1500, Crisiano Ronaldo the 1000th, Andy Cole number 500 and Andrei Kanchelskis the 100th.
description: Scott McTominay, Marcus Rashford and Anthony Martial all scored - despite the latter pair both missing penalties
